(11) Accinelli C et al; J Agric Food Chem 55: 2677-82 (2007)

StringWithMarkup.String: A log Koc of 2.39 (Kd = 9 L/kg), corresponding to a Koc of 245, was measured using an agricultural soil (pH 6.3) from Corrstown, Co Dublin, Ireland(1). Koc values of 49.1 and 45.9 were measured for sulfamethazine in unfertilized silt loam soil (1.6% organic carbon) and in a soil-slurry mixture with a ratio of 50:1 (w/w; 1.6% organic carbon), respectively(2). A Koc value of 60 has been measured for sulfamethazine in clay loam soil(3,4). Koc values measured for sulfamethazine were 174 in sand (pH 5.2, 0.9% organic carbon), 125 in loamy sand (pH 5.6, 2.3% organic carbon), 208 in sandy loam (pH 6.3, 1.2% organic carbon), and 82 in clay silt (pH 6.9, 1.1% organic carbon)(4,5). According to a classification scheme(6), these Koc value suggest that sulfamethazine is expected to have high to moderate mobility in soil. However, aromatic amines are expected to bind strongly to humus or organic matter in soils due to the high reactivity of the aromatic amino group(6,7), suggesting that mobility may be much lower in some soils(SRC). Sulfonamides, which include sulfamethazine, are amphoteric and behave as weak organic acids(9). The pKa of sulfamethazine is 7.65(4), indicating that this compound will exist partially in the anion form in the environment and anions generally do not adsorb more strongly to soils containing organic carbon and clay than their neutral counterparts(10). Sorption coefficients of 6.75 and 4.21 were measured in silt loam (19.9% sand, 56.5% silt, 23.6% clay, pH 7.5, 1.8 organic carbon) and sand (93.5% sand, 2.7% silt, 3.8% clay, pH 7.2, 0.94 organic carbon) soils, respectively, from Minnesota, suggesting high mobility in these soils(11). A Kd value of 15 L/kg was measured using digester sludge from wastewater treatment plant, Dublin, Ireland (pH 6.3)(1).

(2) Tolls J; Environ Sci Technol 35: 3397-406 (2001)

StringWithMarkup.String: The Henry's Law constant for sulfamethazine is estimated as 1.93X10-10 atm-cu m/mole(SRC) using a fragment constant estimation method(1). This Henry's Law constant indicates that the neutral species of sulfamethazine is expected to be essentially nonvolatile from water and moist soil surfaces(2). A pKa of 7.65(2) indicates sulfamethazine will exist almost partially in the anion form at pH values of 5 to 9 and, therefore, volatilization of the ionic form from water surfaces is not expected to be an important fate process(SRC). Sulfamethazine is not expected to volatilize from dry soil surfaces(SRC) based upon an estimated vapor pressure of 6.8X10-9 mm Hg(SRC), determined from a fragment constant method(3).

StringWithMarkup.String: GROUNDWATER: Sulfamethazine was among the antibiotics detected in four of five groundwater samples, one of two tile-drain inlets, and three of four tile-drain outlets in the vicinity of swine feeding operations in Iowa. Concentrations were not specified(1). The concentrations of sulfamethazine were above the quantitation limit (0.02 ug/L) in only 2 out of 59 groundwater samples collected in Germany; the maximum concentration was 0.16 ug/L(2). Manure lagoon well groundwater concentrations in samples from two California diary CAFOs (confined animal feeding operation) employing 8.8 and 10.8 g sulfamethazine/day ranged from 1.1 to 3.6 ug/L and not detected to 0.29 ug/L, respectively(3).

Reference: (1) Batt AL et al; Chemosphere 64: 1963-71 (2006)
(2) Kleywegt S et al; Sci Total Environ 409(8): 1481-88 (2011)

StringWithMarkup.String: DRINKING WATER: Sulfamethazine was present at a range of 0.076 to 0.22 mg/L in six private wells in Washington Co, Weiser, Idaho, formerly used for drinking water. Wells are locate near a confined animal feeding operation(1). The compound was not detected in 258 source or finished drinking water samples from Ontario, Canada, surveyed over a 16-month period in 2006(2).

Reference: (1) Kolpin DW et al; Environ Sci Technol 36: 1202-11 (2002)
(2) Kolpin DW et al; Sci Tot Environ 328: 119-30 (2004)

StringWithMarkup.String: SURFACE WATER: Concentrations of sulfamethazine were above the detection limit (0.05 ug/L) in less than 5% of samples collected between 1999-2000 from 139 stream locations across the United States(1). Median concentrations of sulfamethazine measured in these samples using two separate analytical methods were 0.02 and 0.22 ug/L. Sulfamethazine was not detected (reporting limit 0.01 ug/L) in samples collected upstream and downstream of selected towns and cities of Iowa during 2001(2). The compound was below the detection limit of 4.0 ng/L in surface water samples Lake Michigan in the vicinity of Milwaukee, WI sampled on May 9, 2009 and April 12, 2010(3). Sulfamethazine was not detected in selected north-central and northwestern Arkansas streams, sampled in March, April and August, 2004; reporting limits = 0.05 and 0.005 ug/L(4). Sulfamethazine was present at a concentration range of 1.2-22 ng/L at a 20% frequency in 25 samples from Killbuck Creek (12 samples; urban area) and Buck Creek (13 samples; agricultural area), located in the Upper White River watershed in central Indiana; sampling was conducted over 12 months from June 2009 to May 2010(5).

Reference: (1) Hirsch R et al; Sci Tot Environ 225: 109-18 (1999)
(2) Tamtam F et al; Sci Total Environ 393: 84-95 (2008)
(3) Shimizu A et al; Sci Total Environ 452-453: 108-15 (2013)

StringWithMarkup.String: SURFACE WATER: The concentrations of sulfamethazine were below the quantitation limit of 0.02 ug/L in 52 surface water samples collected in Germany(1). Sulfamethazine was detected (40% frequency) at <10 ngL in Tancaville on the Seine River, France, between Pais and Pose and sampled from January to June, 2006. It was not detected at Poses, LaBouille, Caudebec or Honfleur(2). Sulfamethazine represented 55-78%, 64-84% and 54-82% of the total composition of antibiotics detected in the Mekong river, Manila freshwater, and Manila Bay, respectively. Concentrations of sulfamethazine ranged from 7 on Sept 6 to 4 ng/L on Sept 13, 2009 and 8 ng/L on Dec 8 to 15 ng/L on Dec 8, 2010(3).

Reference: (1) Walraven N, Laane RWPM; Rev Environ Contam Toxicol 199: 1-18 (2008)

StringWithMarkup.String: SEAWATER: Sulfamethazine was detected at a concentration of 15 ng/L in coastal surface water from the Netherlands sampled between 1996 and 2005(1).

StringWithMarkup.String: Sulfamethazine was analyzed for, but not detected in five water samples collected near the Norman Landfill in central Oklahoma in 2000(1). The concentrations of sulfamethazine were below the quantitation limit of 0.02 ug/L in 10 sewage treatment plant effluent samples collected in Germany(2). Sulfamethazine represented on average 50%, 52% and 38% of the total composition of antibiotics detected in sewage in Indonesia, Phillipines and Vietnam, respectively(3). Sulfamethazine was present in industrial waste water at a concentration range of 30-99 ng/L. The compound was not detected in sewage water effluents from the Netherlands sampled in 2002(4).

Reference: (1) Huang CH et al; Occurrence and Fate of Antibiotic Compounds in Municipal Wastewater and Animal Waste. In: Conf Proc -Water Environ Fed Annual Conf and Exposition, 74th, Atlanta, GA, Oct 13-17, 2001 pp. 4532-43 (2001)

StringWithMarkup.String: The estimated concentration of sulfamethazine in the flushwater of a swine confined feeding operation is 971 ug/L based on an average dose of 496 mg/day-animal, a herd of 2500 head of 100-260 pound swine, one thirty-minute flushing period daily, and assuming that up to 80% of the antibiotic is excreted unmetabolized(1). Sulfamethazine represented on average 18-48%, 38-62% and 52-56% of the total composition of antibiotics detected in pig, livestock and shrimp wastewater, respectively, in Vietnam. The compound represented 0-2% of the total composition of antibiotics detected in pig wastewater in Thailand; it was not reported in shrimp aquaculture wastewater in Thailand(2). Manure lagoon concentrations in samples from two California diary CAFOs (confined animal feeding operation) employing 8.8 and 10.8 g sulfamethaine/day ranged from 0.040 to 9.0 ug/L and 0.030 to 0.77 ug/L, respectively. Flush-lane water contained 0.62-7.5 and 0.035-0.25 ug/L, respectively(3).

StringWithMarkup.String: Sulfamethazine was stable in aqueous solution and in milk even after boiling for 15 minutes. Sulfamethazine was stable in kidney (100 mg/g) and in incurred pork meat (300 mg/kg) after boiling, frying, baking, roasting, and grilling(1). The stability of sulfamethazine in raw minced pork was compared with that in minced pork boiled for 60 minutes(1). After 3 weeks, the initial and final concentrations of sulfamethazine were 0.42 and 0.271 mg/g, respectively, in the raw meat; 0.359 and 0.345 mg/g, respectively, in the cooked meat; and 0.159 and 0.15 mg/g, respectively, in the cooking water(1).

StringWithMarkup.String: Sulfamethazine residues in calves on the same day of administration of 99 mg/kg were 30.40 ppm in muscle, 54.90 ppm in the liver, and 43.20 ppm in the kidneys(1). Sulfamethazine residues in sheep 6 hours after administration of 107 mg/kg were 54 ppm in muscle, 69 ppm in the liver, and 124 ppm in the kidneys(1). Sulfamethazine residues in chicken on the same day of administration of 0.1% in water were 5.70 ppm in muscle, 18.70 ppm in the liver, and 10.70 ppm in the kidneys(2). Sulfamethazine residues in chicken on the same day of administration of 0.4% in feed were 74.50 ppm in muscle, 78.00 ppm in the liver, and 103.0 ppm in the kidneys(2). Sulfamethazine residues were dissipated by 99% after 4 days in sheep and calves and after 10 days in chicken(2). Sulfamethazine residues were 45 ppm in egg yolk and 56 ppm in eggwhite from eggs of chickens that were administered a dose of 0.1% in water(2).

StringWithMarkup.String: NIOSH (NOES Survey 1981-1983) has statistically estimated that 17,376 workers (2,625 of these are female) were potentially exposed to sulfamethazine in the US(1). The NOES Survey does not include farm workers. Occupational exposure to sulfamethazine may occur through inhalation and dermal contact with this compound at workplaces where sulfamethazine is produced or used. Monitoring data indicate that the general population may be limited to those living near CAFOs (confined animal feeding operations) via ingestion of contaminated drinking well water(SRC).

Springer Nature aims to provide only highly qualitative and relevant content but references of lower relevance aren't withheld as they might contain also very useful information.

The Anatomical Therapeutic Chemical (ATC) Classification System is used for the classification of drugs. This pharmaceutical coding system divides drugs into different groups according to the organ or system on which they act and/or their therapeutic and chemical characteristics. Each bottom-level ATC code stands for a pharmaceutically used substance, or a combination of substances, in a single indication (or use). This means that one drug can have more than one code: acetylsalicylic acid (aspirin), for example, has A01AD05 as a drug for local oral treatment, B01AC06 as a platelet inhibitor, and N02BA01 as an analgesic and antipyretic. On the other hand, several different brands share the same code if they have the same active substance and indications.

CCSbase is an integrated platform that contains collision cross section data for the compound.  The CCSbase classification groups the compounds by the type of adduct ions that can be formed from them (e.g., [M-H]-, [M+H]+, [M+Na]+, [M+K]+).

Classification from the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency's Distributed Structure-Searchable Toxicity (DSSTox) database. DSSTox provides a high quality public chemistry resource for supporting improved predictive toxicology. A distinguishing feature of this effort is the accurate mapping of bioassay and physicochemical property data associated with chemical substances to their corresponding chemical structures.

Reference.Name: MolGenie Organic Chemistry Ontology
Reference.Description: An organic chemistry ontology developed by MolGenie and OntoChem to assign chemical entities to structural classes, split into three main subsections: calculated properties, compounds and substructural concepts. The ontology contains chemistry structural classes with a focus on elements and small organic compounds, but not inorganic, polymer, biopolymer, metal complexes, metal organic frameworks (MOFs) and other chemistry entities. The ontology has been mapped to several collections of chemicals, including (a) Chemicals of Biological Interest (ChEBI), (b) the ChEMBL database of bioactive molecules, (c) the LOTUS natural product collection, (d) per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances (PFAS) extracted from Barnabas et al (2022) DOI: 10.1039/D2DD00019A (e) PubChemLite and (f) the ZeroPM Global Chemical Inventory.
Reference.LicenseNote: CC-BY 4.0
